subject: ASL0632-ID4740 Ninja build system (Qt5 Porting):
commitMessage:
ASL0632-ID4740 Ninja build system (Qt5 Porting):

* Merged previous Qt3 to Qt4 porting work
* Updated new code changes from Qt3 to Qt4
* Updated debug output to use qPrintable for Qt4
* Widgets library doesn't use default parameters
* Updated QWidgetPlugins to QDesignerCustomWidgetInterface
* Added asl-common/Widgets project files
* Some beautification

Change-Id: I84f49d8b68776c598043db5ac4cf8633fcfa2b73

Patch Set 26:

Hi.
Just a few notes regarding the review. This code change is for porting the code from Qt3 to Qt4, as a result, it's pretty big.

As a result, Vince and I agree that if the old code doesn't conform to coding standards (i.e. with spaces, indentation, anything that is considered minor or cosmetic) then the new code doesn't have to conform.

This will save us a lot of time getting through the code review and will keep the commits to a minimum.

The focus is therefore on removing Qt3 support libraries and making sure that the new code is correct, especially where there wasn't a Qt4 equivalent.

If you're building locally, make sure you're using Qt4 (i.e. with ninja use the '_qt4' suffix to the build folder, with qmake use the correct Qt kit).

It's also worth noting that this change consists of a merge of the previous Qt4 porting work and there were lots of conflicts. So if a change seems unnecessary (or weird) it's probably the result of a merge conflict

FYI, by convention the second line of a commit comment should always be blank (editor's such as vi check this).
Please use a more expansive variable name.

I think these icons should be in the newer 
asl-common/resources/asl-icons.qrc ?
I agree (as well as reviewing all the icons - big job, not for now) but these icons were local to this project so am keeping them local

I know this is not your doing; you've only changed to qPrintable, but these lines are inherently unsafe.  The point returned by qPrintable is valid only in the statement it's used. Saving the temporary pointer is not safe at all:

As ugly as it might be, it would be safer to not save the pointers to local variables, and do the expressions inline.

From https://doc.qt.io/qt-5/qtglobal.html#qPrintable :

"The char pointer will be invalid after the statement in which qPrintable() is used. This is because the array returned by QString::toLocal8Bit() will fall out of scope."
Please keep the comments to the changes JP is making. If you see anything egregious in the course of the review then raise a diary item to capture it.

It also doesn't fix things if reverted to .toLatin1().  However, JP - please don't change anything here relating my my comment (I'll accept qPrintable!).

I have raised ASL0632-ID5650 diary item to note this.

Just to be clear there are two issues here, the change to qPrintable and then the underlying code. The change to qPrintable needs to be reverted for the reasons already given, but the larger issue is not one for JP to fix as part of this change, hence my request for the diary item.
Is there a good reason this was added? We discourage use of #defines (see section 4.11 of the Coding Standard).
What benefit does this bring? Why not just use asl::checkedConnect?

I added a system to support both Qt4 and Qt5 connection syntax using the same mechanism. However, we've since agreed not to update the connection syntax yet so this was removed and this define was left in unintentionally.
Probably but the old code wasn't translatable

Should be: const char* trLabel

(Note position of *)
Variables are snake case (tr_label), not camel case
Where beautification changes are made they need to be consistent, so here you can't leave one line different. BUT... this is now outside of the remit, so please just change it back.

Same, I think these icons should be put in asl-common/resources/asl-icons.qrc 

These were probably missed when Nige made the initial icon consolidation due to them being included int the pri file. 

Same for any others.
This would be outside the Qt4 porting task though
Is this required? It doesn't appear to be used in the header.
This is the .cpp not the header.

This layout does not meet the coding standards. (Comment applies throughout).

As a minimum the colon should be at the start of the next line, but also I think the alignment makes it harder to read.
Please explicitly compare pointers against zero, although in this case I'm not sure the check is even required just after a new.

Please use consistent white spacing. In this case it should be...

( box_ )
This is the header not the cpp.
Your divider comments are a bit broken. There shouldn't be a white space between the start of line and asterisks.
Forward declarations should come after the includes.

Namespaces should match class naming conventions.

ASLWidgets
I think the alignment doesn't aid readability here.

Please either remove the parameter name (comment it out) or use ASL_UNUSED.

We tend to prefer the former approach.
Should be checked against zero. White space is inconsistent.
Does this need to be wrapped?
Should be checked against zero. White space is inconsistent.
Should be checked against zero. White space is inconsistent.

Should match class naming conventions.

ASLWidgets
Could this be a const ref?
Comment out the names or use ASL_UNUSED.
Is this safe? Did you mean dynamic_cast?

Doesn't match naming convention. Should be

ASLWidgets

What does n signify here?

Should be n_rows.
Ok I can see that you have added this to a new GroupFrameBridge() class, but I'm not convinced this is the correct solution.

This way reduces the amount of code changes we need to make when porting existing QGroupBox's to a Qt4 equivalent to a single line.

If QGroupBox changes significantly in the future then we only need to change this class and all instances of it will be fine.
Check against zero. Please use consistent white spacing.
You could refactor this code to remove one of the checks on box_ being valid.
Return type should be on its own line.
This is going to override any stylesheet code we have in the ASL global style.
This was before I started adding stylesheets for custom widgets. I'll add a TODO comment and get back to it later.
I'm re-evaluating this class as it doesn't seem that necessary now

Member variables should be private in scope and in a separate scope block.

Naming convention is underscore separated like_this and not likeThis.
Doesn't satisfy coding standards - colon should be at the start of the next line.

ASLs library. A lot of the classes are horrendous with Qt, std etc library includes and declarations mixed in with the project and ASL library ones. Thought this was a tidy and concise way of organising these.

Although, I've just realised the cmath library here. I'll take out the comments

Spaces not tabs.

Probably, but the original string wasn't translatable
You only need to change one line here.
THis will set single shot mode permanently.
Not a problem as all calls to start() are single shot. Let me know if they're not
My point is more that this only needs to be done once.

This is going to permanently set the timer into single shot mode. Is that what is wanted?

If it is, this change could be added where the timer is created, more efficient to just call it once. I can see a similar change higher up too).

This will set the timer into single shot mode permanently - this is different to what the code did before. Is this what you intended?

If so, the change should be made where the timer is created/initialised.
Not raising the same comment here as start is only called once (i.e. here).
This changes the behaviour of the code. Is it intended?
Yes, it's always a single shot as far as I can tell
But it only needs to be done once.
This only needs to be done in once place.
Only needs to be done in one place.

Missing divider.

Return type should be on separate line.

This is a great example of what I've been getting at with my comments on the timers.

You have permanently set the health tick timer into single shot mode. This changes the behaviour/design of the class and I am not sure if you meant to. That timer is started elsewhere without the second parameter. Previously would have started a repeating timer and now a single shot.
Done. All the timers I've modified as part of this review have been single shot timers. This is the only one that isn't.

What does 'done' mean in this context? How have you changed this?

Looking at the old behaviour I think there is a bug here. The first time the two parameter version of start is called the timer will be put into single shot anyway - if the other version gets called first it will be potentially repeating.

Done means I've acknowledged your comment and made changes (if required) to consider the points raised. In this case it was checking the start() calls to see if they were all single shot. Task_tick is never a single shot so we don't need this line but health_tick is both depending on its usage.

The behaviour should be the same as long as the setSingleShot calls are correct.

This is a change in resize behavior. 

Q3ListView::AllColumns - sized the coloumns equally 

resizeColumnsToContents() resizes the coloumns to their optimum size. In my experience this makes the coloums adjust size when the user scrolls up/down the table (which is nasty).
Do you know the equivalent in Qt4? Other than intercepting the QResizeEvent and manually setting the column widths I can't see a simple way of doing this
As this is a QTableWidget, I'm pretty sure you can just call setRowCount(0) to clear the table, then that leaves the header row intact.

The comment referred to what happened if all the processEvents() methods were removed. It also dated to before we built our own Qt.

processOneEvent() is the perfect method because it means we break out of the loop as soon as possible (i.e. as soon as the event that means we've signed in has happened). The line you've substituted will work, but the timeout period is wrong. If the system is busy, you will keep processing events until the timeout, even if you could have exited the loop earlier. So instead of jcop_connection_timeout_ms_ + 10 you should specify a small value like 20ms. This way the loop will never exit more than 20ms later than it "could".
I think I would just remove the comment.

Ah yes. How about using removeOne?
The original remove() removes all of the items as far as I'm aware

I don't believe this is correct - calling the form of remove which takes an iterator would remove only the item at that position.

I think either removeOne() or removeAll() could probably be used here safely, but to maintain the same functionality I'd go with removeOne() here.
Yes I made a mistake, there are two remove() functions in QValueList. So, removeOne() will do what we need and there's no need to get the index / iterator either
